docs.lead_paragraph: The tax package that the White House negotiated with Congressional leaders offers few redeeming features. It would do little to spur investment. It would tilt the tax code in favor of high-income families. It would create huge deficits after several years that will force Congress to squeeze hard on Federal programs. But there is an imaginative way to amend it to produce at least one useful outcome -- medical insurance for children. The tax plan includes a $500-per-child tax credit, a pro-consumption feature that does not belong in a deficit-reduction package. Eugene Steuerle of the Urban Institute, who was a tax official in the Reagan Administration, suggests offering the new credit only to parents who provide medical insurance for their children. The underlying principle -- government help, but only in exchange for individual action -- should be attractive to a President and Congress that embraced that notion in last year's welfare-to-work law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Big German Union Accepts Pact Leading to Wage Cuts A union representing Germany's 600,000 chemical workers agreed to a contract that opens the possibility for troubled companies to reduce wages by 10 percent -- a bow toward workplace flexibility in a country that has lost more than a million jobs in five years. Business leaders welcomed the pact, which comes at a time of insecurity in German industry over global competitiveness. The contract, covering about 1,700 companies, including Hoechst A.G., BASF and Bayer A.G., was the sharpest departure to date from Germany's ironclad work rules. $(Page A1.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: In one of the sharpest moves yet in the nationwide backlash against the power of health maintenance organizations, Texas will soon become the first state where consumers will be explicitly allowed to sue their H.M.O.'s for medical malpractice. ''The delivery of health care has changed over the past decade,'' said David Sibley, a doctor and Republican state senator from Waco who successfully sponsored the Texas legislation. ''Dr. Marcus Welby is dead. A third party has inserted itself into the treatment room, operation room and examination room. And I can think of no reason why a doctor should be held accountable for a decision but an H.M.O. should not.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Too many Americans are denied a chance to die well because of inadequate care and lack of understanding of their needs, an expert panel from the Institute of Medicine said today. The 12-member panel said many Americans suffered preventable pain and stress at the end of life. The experience is so poorly managed by doctors and other health workers, as well as insurers, that many people see death as a degrading, painful episode that leads to talk of assisted suicide, the panelists said.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans today unveiled details of their plan to slow the growth of Medicare by cutting payments to hospitals, doctors and other health care providers, but they backed away from some of the more radical proposals that provoked a veto by President Clinton in 1995. Mr. Clinton has already endorsed the total amount of projected savings, $115 billion, or 8.5 percent of what Medicare would otherwise spend in the next five years. But he has objected to some parts of the Republican plan, including a proposal to allow medical savings accounts for the elderly as an alternative to standard Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Anthem Inc., an Indianapolis insurance brokerage company, said yesterday that it would pay $40 a share, or about $170 million, to acquire the shares of Acordia Inc. it did not already own, adding to its health insurance business. Shares of Acordia surged $4, or 11 percent, to $39.50, after a delayed New York Stock Exchange opening. Anthem, a closely held health care manager based in Indianapolis, already owned 66.8 percent of Acordia. Anthem said it would buy the Acordia shares in a tender offer expected to begin by June 6.

docs.lead_paragraph: Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut, which had been among the nation's dwindling number of community hospitals striving to remain independent, announced yesterday that it was affiliating with the Yale-New Haven Health System. ''It's not a merger or an acquisition,'' said Frank A. Corvino, the president and chief executive of Greenwich. ''It's a strategic alliance, in which the Greenwich Health Care System will have a new parent.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The Physician Corporation of America said yesterday that it was in talks with an unnamed partner to be bought for $7 a share, or $266 million, two months after a previous suitor abandoned an agreement to buy the managed-care company. The Miami-based company said in February that it would take an $80 million charge to cover claims from workers' compensation insurance policies. In March, Sierra Health Services Inc. ended an agreement to buy Physician, citing widening losses at the division. That agreement was valued at $11.81 a share. Shares of Physician, which also operates health maintenance organizations, fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $6.25, in Nasdaq trading.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was Danny Nelson's second day on the job as a pipe fitter for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and he was deep in the catacombs beneath Grand Central Terminal, repairing an expansion joint on a steam pipe as wide as a barrel and sheathed with asbestos. Mr. Nelson, a junior high school dropout who can neither read nor write, hacked at the insulation with hatchet, hammer or wrench -- whatever tool was at hand. In the sweltering tunnel, where temperatures reach 140 degrees, he was sticky with sweat and the white flakes clung to his skin, his hair, his clothes. A leak in one of the pipes sent the steam screaming, shredding the asbestos and pushing it for blocks, as if shot from a gun.
